Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Acquisition of a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer by Trinity University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) program Professor Nancy S. Mills and colleagues Jessica Hollenbeck, Laura Hunsicker-Wang and Adam R. Urbach from the Department of Chemistry at Trinity University will acquire a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer equipped with a broad band probe. The instrument will be used to support research activities such as: 1) probing the conformational flexibility of designed ankyrin-repeat proteins; 2) studying the cooperation of intermolecular interactions within the framework of a rigid DNA duplex in complexes containing polyamide ligands; 3) examination of the pH dependence of the redox behavior of Rieske proteins through chemical modification of potential titratable groups to characterize modified amino acids; and 4) evaluation of interactions of lithium counterions with antiaromatic dianions.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Trinity University is a predominantly undergraduate institution, with a particularly strong research program in the Department of Chemistry. Through the large undergraduate research program in the department, more than 40 students each summer are involved in undergraduate research, frequently as early as the summer following their first year in college. The majority of students work in areas that require the use of NMR spectrometry. Acquisition of the NMR spectrometer has resulted in the development of very strong research skills in this group of future chemists and health care professionals. In the Urbach research group, the NMR spectrometer has been a crucial instrument used in the synthesis of artificial receptors and the analysis of their interaction with a wide range of peptides and proteins. The extra resolution and sensitivity of this instrument have been particularly important for analyzing complex and precious samples. The receptors can include molecules that respond to light to indicate interactions at a very low concentration, which have enabled his group to use these receptors to develop a novel sensor for insulin and new methods for high-throughput detection of peptide interactions. The Mills group is examining a group of compounds that were predicted by theory to be very unstable but which offer the opportunity to understand one of the most important, but poorly understood, theories of organic chemistry, aromaticity. In essence, the Mills compounds, which are examples of antiaromatic compounds, are much more sensitive detectors of changes in the behavior of aromatic compounds.  The disperson of this instrument has played a key role in the determination of the structures of these compounds. Dr. Hollenbeck's group is examining the interaction that occurs in the body between proteins and carbohydrates by using a protein as a scaffold for the attachment of sugars. By varying the distances between the attached sugars, the glycoprotein can be tuned to recognize specific proteins through that attached sugars. The Hunsicker-Wang lab is looking to identify certain NMR signals that correlated with specific properties of the protein.
